node.name: Category
node.description: This is meant to designate the basic nature of the event. Every event should have at least one category, but might have multiple categories.

node.name: Sensory presentation
node.description: Something perceivable by the participant.

node.name: Experimental
node.description: Primary category for task-or-condition-related stimulus events.

node.name: Environmental
node.description: An unplanned or environment-determined event occurring in the environment of the participant, for example, a change in experimental context such as beginning to walk on dirt versus sidewalk or a loud noise occurring in the next room.

node.name: Participant action
node.description: Any motor action engaged in by the participant.

node.name: Task-related
node.description: A task-related action taken by a participant in response to task demands, such as making a button press in response to a Sensory presentation event or tapping out a rhythm following a Condition cue presentation.

node.name: Non task-related
node.description: A non-task-related action taken by the participant -- for example yawning, shifting in their chair, or responding to an Environmental event

node.name: Data feature
node.description: An event derived from the data itself, possibly inserted in a post-hoc fashion, for example an interictal spike or alpha burst.

node.name: Experiment Control
node.description: An event pertaining to the setup and/or control of the experiment.

node.name: Condition
node.description: An event used to indicate a shift to a new experimental and/or task condition. Use (Attribute/Temporal/Onset, Attribute/Temporal/Duration) or Attribute/Temporal/Onset and, in another Event, Attribute/Temporal/Offset to specify start and end. Use Attribute/ID/Index/# to designate a condition identifier.

node.name: Instruction
node.description: Experimenter (or experimental control application) gives an instruction to the participant.

node.name: Pause
node.description: An event indicating a stop in recording. Use (Attribute/Temporal/Onset, Attribute/Temporal/Duration) or Attribute/Temporal/Onset and, in another Event, Attribute/Temporal/Offset to specify the length of the pause.

node.name: Timesync
node.description: A marker value or pattern inserted into the recorded data to allow post hoc synchronization of concurrently recorded data streams.

node.name: Procedure
node.description: An event marking the Onset or Offset of an experimental procedure, for example doing a saliva swab on the person, during the experiment. Use Attribute/Temporal/Onset and, in another Event, Attribute/Temporal/Offset to specify the start and end of the procedure. Use Attribute/ID/Index/# to designate a procedure identifier.

node.name: Mishap
node.description: Unplanned disruptive event such as an equipment or experiment control abnormality or experimenter error.

node.name: Description
node.description: Human-readable text description of the event.

node.name: Label
node.description: A label for the event with less than 20 characters, for example, Event/Label/Accept button press. Please note that the information in this tag is provided for analyst guidance in referring to this and similar events in the context of the study, rather than for direct use in the analysis process. Please use tag stem Event/Category/Custom to define custom event description hierarchies not meant for inclusion in this main HED schema. Also, please do not use the words Onset or Offset in the Event/Label. These should only be placed in Attribute/Temporal/Onset and Attribute/Temporal/Offset attribute descriptors. This makes it easier to automatically find onsets and offsets for the same event.

node.name: Long label
node.description: A longer (than 20 characters) label for the event that may contain | characters as separators. Long names are used to encode detailed information in a single string such as Scenario | VehiclePassing | TravelLaneBLocked | Onset

node.name: Object
node.description: Physical object perceptible via Visual, Auditory, Olfactory, and/or Tactile modalities

node.name: Manmade
node.description: A manmade object

node.name: Building
node.description: Whole building or building feature

node.name: Furnishing
node.description: The instrumentalities (furniture and appliances and other movable accessories including curtains and rugs) that make a home (or other area) livable

node.name: Tool
node.description: A hand-held object of single person control

node.name: Artwork
node.description: A work of art that is primarily visual in character

node.name: Document
node.description: A physical, written document

node.name: Language
node.description: Perceivable in a visual or auditory (spoken) sensory presentation

node.name: Cocktail party
node.description: Multiple speech streams at once

node.name: Environmental
node.description: A background sound from the surrounding environment. For example machine operating or people walking
A text-description of a complex environmental sound

node.name: Action
node.description: May or may not be in response to a previous Sensory presentation event.

node.name: Inhale
node.description: A deliberate inbreath, e.g. in response to a task instruction. If incidental, use Action/Movement/Incidental/Inspiration

node.name: Exhale
node.description: A deliberate outbreath, e.g. in response to a task instruction. If incidental, use Action/Movement/Incidental/Expiration

node.name: Heel strike
node.description: Takes attribute Attribute/Spatial/Object side/Left or Attribute/Spatial/Object side/Right.

node.name: Toe off
node.description: Takes attribute Attribute/Spatial/Object side/Left or Attribute/Spatial/Object side/Right.

node.name: Drop
node.description: For example the participant drops a handheld ball

node.name: Press
node.description: As in pressing a button. Release may be quick or delayed. This can be used also for other types of pushing actions and can be grouped with Item/Object/Human/Body part tag to indicate which part of the body was used to press the button.

node.name: Release
node.description: As in releasing a pressed button. Release events are not frequently recorded as Participant action events unless their timing is task-relevant.

node.name: Tap
node.description: A quick press, followed by a quick release

node.name: Reach
node.description: Requires a spatial goal such as reaching to touch a button or to grasp something. A body stretch is not a reach.

node.name: Touch
node.description: May follow a Reach event

node.name: Grasp
node.description: Grasp an object in one or both hands

node.name: Point
node.description: Should be grouped with Item/Agent/Human/Body part/Hand/Finger tag to specify which finger was used for the action.

node.name: Jerk
node.description: When some force applied to the participant causes them to involuntary accommodate or react to it.

node.name: Stumble
node.description: Temporary and involuntary loss of balance

node.name: Recover balance
node.description: A movement made in response to a stumble or unforeseen loss of balance

node.name: Fall
node.description: Involuntary fall to floor or ground

node.name: Stretch
node.description: Stretching the body or body part

node.name: Speak
node.description: Communicate using spoken language.

node.name: Gestural
node.description: Make a expressive communicative movement of hands/arms and, often, face

node.name: Vocalize
node.description: Make a sustained vowel sound such as, Ahhh

node.name: Intramodal
node.description: In the same modality but with a change in details such as changing from paying attention to red dots and instead of blue dots

node.name: Intermodal
node.description: Between modalities such as changing from audio to visual

node.name: Allow
node.description: Allow access to something such as allowing a car to pass

node.name: Deny
node.description: Deny access to something such as preventing someone to pass

node.name: Neutral
node.description: None of the above

node.name: ID
node.description: Tag to identify any aspect of an event. Use parentheses to group an ID Value tag with an ID Type tag to qualify the kind of ID that the value represents.
Experiment parameters in some a string. Do not used quotes.

node.name: Modality
node.description: Presentation modality by which the object was manifested.

node.name: Direction
node.description: Coordinate system is inferred from Attribute/Location. To specify a vector combine subnodes with number --- for example Attribute/Top/10, Attribute/Direction/Left/5 to create a vector with coordinates 10 and 5

node.name: Location
node.description: Spot or center of an area. Use Area were you are referring to something with significant extent and emphasizing its boundaries, like a city

node.name: Duration
node.description: An offset that is implicit after duration time passed from the onset

node.name: Onset
node.description: Default

node.name: Repetition
node.description: When the same type of event such as a fixation on the exact same object happens multiple times and it might be necessary to distinguish the first look vs. others

node.name: Response start delay
node.description: The time interval between this (stimulus) event and the start of the response event specified, usually by grouping with the event ID of the response start event.

node.name: Response end delay
node.description: The time interval between this (stimulus) event and the end of the response event specified, usually by grouping with the event ID of the response end event.

node.name: Rate
node.description: Number of occurrences in a unit of time.

node.name: Uncertainty
node.description: Use to specify the amount of uncertainty in the timing of the event. Please notice that this is different from Attribute/Probability tag which relates to the occurrence of event and can be interpretative as the integral of probability density across a distribution whose shape (temporal extent) is specified by Attribute/Temporal uncertainty

node.name: Imagined
node.description: This is used to identity that the (sub)event only happened in the imagination of the participant, e.g. imagined movements in motor imagery paradigms.

node.name: Intended effect
node.description: How the stimulus is expected to effect the participants

node.name: Warning
node.description: As in a warning message that you are getting too close to the shoulder in a driving task

node.name: Oddball
node.description: Unexpected or infrequent

node.name: Target
node.description: Something the subject is looking for

node.name: Non-target
node.description: Make sure to tag Expected if the Non-target is frequent

node.name: Novel
node.description: Genuinely novel such as an event occurring once or so per experiment

node.name: Expected
node.description: Of low information value, for example frequent Non-targets in an RSVP paradigm

node.name: Valid
node.description: Something that is understood to be valid such as an ID matches the person being displayed and it has all the correct information

node.name: Invalid
node.description: Something that is understood to not be valid such as like an ID with an impossible date-of-birth, or a photo not matching the person presenting it

node.name: Condition
node.description: Specifies the value of an independent variable (number of letters, N, in an N-back task) or function of independent variables that is varied or controlled for in the experiment. This attribute is often specified at the task level and can be associated with specification of an experimental stimulus or an experiment context (e.g. 1-back, 2-back conditions in an N-back task, or changing the target type from faces to houses in a Rapid Serial Visual Presentation, or RSVP, task.)
the condition

node.name: Action judgment
node.description: External judgment (assumed to be ground truth, e.g. from an experiment control software or an annotator) about participant actions such as answering a question, failing to answer in time, etc.

node.name: Incorrect
node.description: Wrong choice but not time out

node.name: Indeterminate
node.description: It cannot be determined that the action was correct or incorrect.

node.name: Missed
node.description: Participant failed or could not have perceived the instruction due to their eyes being off-screen or a similar reason. Not easy to deduce this but it is possible

node.name: Inappropriate
node.description: A choice that is not allowed such as moving a chess piece to a location it should not go based on game rules

node.name: Social
node.description: Involving interactions among multiple agents such as humans or dogs or robots

node.name: Peak
node.description: Peak velocity or acceleration or jerk

node.name: Item count
node.description: Number of items for example when there are 3 cars and they are identified as a single item

node.name: Ramp up
node.description: Increasing in amplitude

node.name: Ramp down
node.description: Decreasing in amplitude

node.name: Time shut
node.description: The amount of time the eyelid remains closed (typically measured as 90% of the blink amplitude), in seconds.

node.name: Duration
node.description: Duration of blink, usually the half-height blink duration in seconds taken either from base or zero of EEG signal. For eye-trackers, usually denotes interval when pupil covered by eyelid.

node.name: PAVR
node.description: Amplitude-Velocity ratio, in centiseconds

node.name: NAVR
node.description: Negative Amplitude-Velocity ratio, in centiseconds

node.name: Change
node.description: Use onset and offset attributes to indicate different walking stride phases

node.name: Faster
node.description: Increasing the speed of walking

node.name: Slower
node.description: Decreasing the speed of walking

node.name: Up-down separated
node.description: Stimuli presented both at the top and the bottom of fovea

node.name: Bilateral
node.description: For bilateral visual field stimulus presentations

node.name: Nonlinguistic
node.description: Something that conveys meaning without using words such as the iconic pictures of a man or a woman on the doors of restrooms. Another example is a deer crossing sign with just a picture of jumping deer.

node.name: Semantic
node.description: Like in priming or in congruence

node.name: Induced
node.description: Such as inducing emotions or keeping someone awake or in a coma with an external intervention

node.name: Arousal
node.description: Only in the context of 2D emotion representation

node.name: Positive valence
node.description: Valence by itself can be the name of an emotion such as sadness so this tag distinguishes the type of emotion

node.name: Supraliminal
node.description: By default this is assumed about each stimulus

node.name: Liminal
node.description: At the 75%-25% perception threshold

node.name: Probability
node.description: Use to specify the level of certainty about the occurrence of the event. Use either numerical values as the child node or low, high, etc.

node.name: Presentation
node.description: Attributes associated with visual, auditory, tactile, etc. presentation of an stimulus

node.name: Fraction
node.description: the fraction of presentation of an Oddball or Expected stimuli to the total number of same-class presentations, e.g. 10% of images in an RSVP being targets

node.name: Cued
node.description: what is presented is cued to the presentation of something else

node.name: Background
node.description: presented in the background such as background music, background image, etc. The main factor here is that background presentations are to be ignored, e.g. ignore math question auditory stimuli.

node.name: Intended effect
node.description: This tag is to be grouped with Participant/Effect/Cognitive to specify the intended cognitive effect (of the experimenter). This is to differentiate the resulting group with Participant/Effect which specifies the actual effect on the participant. For example, in an RSVP experiment if an image is intended to be perceived as a target, (Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target, Attribute/Intended effect) group is added. If the image was perceived by the subject as a target (e.g. they pressed a button to indicate so), then the tag Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target is also added: Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target, (Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target, Attribute/Intended effect). otherwise the Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target tag is not included outside of the group.

node.name: Instruction
node.description: This tag is placed in events of type Event/Category/Experiment Control/Instruction, grouped with one or more Action/ tags to replace the detailed specification XXX in Event/Category/Experimental Control/Instruction/XXX) in previous versions. Usage example: Event/Category/Experimental Control/Instruction, (Action/Fixate, Attribute/Instruction)

node.name: Participant indication
node.description: This tag is placed in events of type Event/Category/Participant response and grouped with Participant/Effect/Cognitive/.. tags to specify the type of cognitive effect the participant has experienced. For example, in an RSVP paradigm, the subject can indicate the detection of a target with a button press. The HED string associated with this button press must include (Attribute/Participant indication, Participant/Effect/Cognitive/Target,...)

node.name: Velocity
node.description: Use Attribute/Temporal/Onset or Attribute/Temporal/Offset to specify onset or offset

node.name: Constrained
node.description: For example a path cannot cross some region

node.name: File
node.description: File attributes

node.name: Object control
node.description: Specifies control such as for a vehicle

node.name: Another person
node.description: Item such as a cup belonging to another person

node.name: Same person
node.description: Item such as a cup belonging to the participant

node.name: Extraneous
node.description: Button presses that are not meaningful for example due to intrinsic mechanical causes after a meaningful press

node.name: Role
node.description: The role of the agent (participant, character, AI..)

node.name: Teleoperate
node.description: Control an object that you are not aboard

node.name: Experiment context
node.description: Describes the context of the whole experiment or large portions of it and also includes tags that are common across all events

node.name: Prone
node.description: As in on a bed

node.name: Indoors
node.description: Default

node.name: Clinic
node.description: Recording in a clinical setting such as in a hospital or medical office

node.name: Motion platform
node.description: Subject is on a motion platform such as one that produces simulated car movements

node.name: Distance
node.description: Assuming static subject
Distance from subject eyes to the presentation screen for 30 cm from subject eyes to the monitor
Default units are pixels
Default units are pixels

node.name: Custom
node.description: This node can be used to organize events in an alternative (parallel) hierarchy. You can define your custom tags and hierarchies without any restriction under this node. These tags will still be matched to each other as for example /Custom/Dance/Waltz is considered a subtype of /Custom/DanceExample.
